questions.text: A 67-year-old diabetic male presents with acute onset of severe joint pain, swelling, and redness without any preceding trauma. He is febrile (38.5°C), and laboratory tests reveal elevated CRP and neutrophilic leukocytosis. Arthrocentesis yields purulent synovial fluid. Which joint is most commonly involved in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
The knee joint is the most frequently involved site in septic arthritis across all age groups.

Septic Arthritis:

  • This is an arthritis caused by pyogenic organisms.
  • Other terms often used to describe this condition are pyogenic arthritis, infective arthritis or suppurative arthritis.
  • It is more common in children, and males are more susceptible. Other predisposing factors are poor hygiene, poor resistance, diabetes, etc.
  • Staphylococcus aureusis the commonest causative organism.
  • The knee is the most commonly affected joint. Other joints commonly affected are the hip, shoulder, elbow, etc.
  • As the organism reaches the joint by various routes(hematogenous/direct trauma), there begins an inflammatory response in the synovium, resulting in the exudation of fluid within the joint. Joint cartilage is destroyed by inflammatory granulation tissue and lysosomal enzymes in the joint exudate. The outcome varies from complete healing to destruction of the joint. The latter may result in a complete loss of joint movement(ankylosis).
  • Septic arthritis presents with a severe throbbing pain, swelling and redness of the affected joint. This is associated with high-grade fever and malaise.
  • Bloodshows neutrophilic leucocytosis. ESR is markedly elevated. A blood culture may grow the causative organism. Joint aspiration is the quickest and best method of diagnosing septic arthritis. The fluid may show features of acute septic inflammation.
  • A combination of Ceftriaxone and Cloxacillin, in appropriate doses, is usually given. These are subsequently changed to specific antibiotics as per aspirate culture and sensitivity reports. The joint must be put to rest in a splint or in traction.

Explanation of other options:

Shoulder (Option B): Less frequently involved; often seen in IV drug users or post-injection.

Hip (Option C): Common in neonates and infants but not the primary site in older adults.

Elbow (Option D): May be affected, but is far less common than the knee.

Key Takeaway:

The knee joint is the most commonly affected site in septic arthritis, particularly in diabetic and elderly patients.

choices.text: Spread from adjacent proximal femoral osteomyelitis

questions.text: What is the most common route of transmission of septic arthritis of the hip in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Septic arthritis of the hip in children most commonly occurs due to hematogenous dissemination from distant foci.

Etiology Of Septic Arthritis:

Staphylococcus aureus is the commonest causative organism. Other organisms are Streptococcus, Pneumococcus. The organisms reach the joint by one of the following routes:

  • Haematogenous:This is the commonest route. There may be a primary focus of infection in the form of pyoderma, throat infection, septicaemia, etc.
  • Secondary to nearby osteomyelitis:This is a particularly common route in joints with intraarticular metaphysis, e.g., the hip, shoulder, etc.
  • Penetrating wounds:The knee, being a superficial joint, is often affected via this route.
  • Iatrogenic:This may occur following intraarticular steroid injections in different arthritis, and during femoral artery punctures for blood collection.
  • Umbilical cord sepsisin infants can travel to the joints.

Explanation of other options:

Spread from adjacent proximal femoral osteomyelitis (Option B): Less common than hematogenous spread, though anatomically possible in hip joints.

Direct traumatic inoculation (Option C): Possible but rare, more likely in superficial joints like the knee.

Post-surgical infection (Option D): Seen in iatrogenic or hospital-acquired cases; uncommon in initial presentation.

Key Takeaway:

Hematogenous spread is the most common route for septic arthritis of the hip in children.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of osteoarthritis presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of right knee pain and swelling. He has no history of similar symptoms. He denies trauma, fever, or pain in any other joints. On examination, he is afebrile. The right knee is swollen, erythematous, and painful with passive range of motion. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. An arthrocentesis is performed, which shows purulent fluid and a leukocyte count of 90,000/μL with 90% neutrophils. No crystals are seen on polarized microscopy. Gram stain and culture are pending. What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Purulent synovial fluid with high neutrophil count and no crystals confirms septic arthritis.

  • Septic arthritis should be suspected in acute monoarthritis with joint warmth, swelling, and restricted motion, especially in the elderly.
  • Synovial fluid analysis:
    • Turbid/purulent fluid
    • WBC >50,000/μL, mostly neutrophils
    • Negative for crystals
  • Most common causative organism: Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Prompt diagnosis and IV antibiotics are critical to prevent cartilage destruction and ankylosis.

Explanation of other options:

Gout (Option A): Presents with needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals in synovial fluid.

Synovial effusion (Option B): Is a descriptive term, not a diagnosis-seen in many joint pathologies, including trauma and inflammation, but not purulent or diagnostic by itself.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option C): Usually chronic, polyarticular, and not purulent. Synovial fluid shows a lower WBC count, predominantly lymphocytes.

Key Takeaway:

A purulent, neutrophil-rich synovial aspirate without crystals points toward septic arthritis.

choices.text: Upper end of tibia is the most common site
Usually there is no discharging sinus
Spine is the most commonly affected

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Garré's osteomyelitis is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Spine is not the most commonly involved site in Garré's osteomyelitis; it most often affects the mandible and long bones like the upper tibia or femur shaft.

  • Garré's osteomyelitis is a sclerosing, chronic, non-suppurative form of osteomyelitis. (Option B ruled out)
  • Most common sites: mandible, upper end of tibia, and femur shaft. (Option A ruled out)
  • It is often seen in younger patients, especially adolescents.
  • There is no discharging sinus, and the condition shows onion-skin periosteal reaction on radiographs. (Option D ruled out)
  • Management is usually conservative but may include decortication.

Key Takeaway: Garré's osteomyelitis is a chronic, sclerosing, non-suppurative form of osteomyelitis that spares the spine and mainly involves the mandible or long bones.

choices.text: 2 weeks IV and 2 weeks oral
2 weeks IV and 4 weeks oral
4 weeks IV and 2 weeks oral
4 weeks IV and 4 weeks oral

questions.text: Total duration of antibiotics in acute osteomyelitis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

6 weeks of treatment for acute osteomyelitis.

If acute osteomyelitis is suspected on clinical grounds, blood and fluid samples should be taken for laboratory investigation, and then treatment is started immediately without waiting for final confirmation of the diagnosis

There are four important aspects to the management of the patient:

  • Supportive treatment of pain(analgesic) and dehydration.
  • Splinting of the affected part to provide comfort and to prevent contracture.
  • Appropriate antimicrobial therapy: 2 weeks intravenous and 4 weeks oral(total 6 weeks).
  • Surgical drainage - Surgical drainage is indicated
    1. If there is no improvement within 24-48 hours of IV antibiotics.
    2. Formation of abscess.
  • Surgical methods includes Aspiration, incision and drainage, multiple drill holes or small bone window, depending on the situation.

Key Takeaway:

The standard duration of antibiotic therapy for acute osteomyelitis is 6 weeks, typically 2 weeks IV + 4 weeks oral.

questions.text:
Which of the following are not included in the original Kocher's criteria used to differentiate septic arthritis from transient synovitis of the hip joint in children?
1. Weight-bearing joint
2. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) > 40 mm/hr
3. White blood cell (WBC) count > 12,000/mm³
4. C-reactive protein (CRP) > 2.5 mg/L
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kocher's criteria are used to differentiate septic arthritis of the hip joint from transient synovitis hip in children. It has four components; 1 point is assigned to each component.
  • Originally CRP was not a part of Kocher's criteria.
  • It was added later by Caird et al. CRP is the most sensitive of all lab criteria. Order of sensitivity of the above criteria: fever > CRP > ESR > refusal to bear weight > WBC

questions.text: The Earliest radiological feature of TB spine is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The earliest radiological sign in spinal tuberculosis is a reduction in the intervertebral disc space, typically seen in the paradiscal type, which is the most common form.

  • The classic triad of TB spine is disk space reduction, lysis of the vertebra and paravertebral soft tissue abscesses.
  • Disk space reduction is the earliest finding, seen in the commoner paravertebral type of tuberculosis. It is due to a lack of nutrition or prolapse of the nucleus pulposus into the soft cancellous deceased body.
  • Thereafter, the contiguous margins of the affected vertebrae get eroded. With further destruction of the vertebral body, there is anterior wedging of the vertebra leading to kyphotic deformity.
  • Bone and joint tuberculosis constitutes 1-4 per cent of the total number of cases of tuberculosis.
  • Systemic features of infection, such as fever, do not commonly occur in bone and joint TB.
  • The spine is the commonest site of bone and joint tuberculosis.
  • Dorsolumbar spine is the commonest region to get affected; Paradiscal being the commonest type.
  • It is the neurological complications associated with spine TB that are of serious concern.
  • TB hip is a common cause of monoarthritis in children. Early diagnosis can save the joint from developing ankylosis.
  • TB knee is of two types: Synovial and articular.
  • Joints get affected early if there is a juxta-articular tubercular osteomyelitis.
  • Treatment is focused on (a) control of the disease, (b) functional recovery.
  • Healing of tuberculous arthritis occurs by fibrous ankylosis.
  • TB osteomyelitis is common in small bones

Explanation of other options:

Vertebral body destruction (Option B): Occurs after disc involvement; not the first feature.

Knuckle deformity (Option C): Develops after vertebral collapse, typically seen in late disease.

Vertebral sclerosis (Option D): Not a hallmark of early TB; rather, seen in healing or chronic pyogenic infections.

questions.text: Hong Kong operation is done for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Hong Kong procedure refers to radical anterior spinal decompression and fusion, originally described and widely practised in Hong Kong for tubercular spondylitis.

Hong Kong procedure(Radical anterior decompression and spinal fusion):

  • It is a radical anterior debridement of the spine followed by removal of the diseased vertebral body and bone grafting in the area of the removed body.
  • It helps in early healing of the disease and also prevents a deformity in a better way, but it needs appropriate facilities.
  • It is usually done in cervical spine TB.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoarthritis (Option B): Managed by NSAIDs, physiotherapy, and joint replacement; no role for anterior spinal debridement.

Osteoporosis (Option C): Managed medically; spinal surgery is rare and limited to fractures.

Synovitis (Option D): Treated with rest, NSAIDs, or synovectomy; not with bone grafting or debridement.

choices.text: Stretching of the spinal cord in gibbus deformity

questions.text: In Pott's spine, which of the following is not a cause of paraplegia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paravertebral disc oedema is not a known direct compressive factor in spinal tuberculosis leading to paraplegia. Pott's paraplegia occurs because of pressure on the neural tissues within the canal by products from the diseased vertebrae. It could occur in the following ways:

  • Inflammatory oedema:The neural tissues become oedematous because of vascular stasis in the adjacent diseased area.
  • Extradural pus and granulation tissue:This is the commonest cause of compression on neural structures. The abscess formed around the diseased vertebrae may compress the neural structures from the front, much the same way as an extradural tumour.
  • Sequestra:Devascularised bone and extruded disc material may be displaced into the canal.
  • Internal 'gibbus':Angulation of the diseased spine may lead to the formation of the bony ridge on the anterior wall of the spinal canal. This is called the internal gibbus
  • Infarction of the spinal cord:This is an unusual but important cause of paralysis. It results from the blockage of the anterior spinal artery, caused by the inflammatory reaction.
  • Extradural granuloma:Very rarely, an extradural granuloma may form without any damage to the osseous structures. Such a patient presents with a clinical picture of a spinal tumour - the so-called 'Spinal tumour syndrome'.

Explanation of other options:

Stretching of the spinal cord in gibbus deformity (Option A): Mechanical stretching over the internal gibbus is a recognised cause.

Compression by granulation tissue (Option C): The Commonest cause of Pott's paraplegia.

Oedema of the spinal cord (Option D): Inflammatory cause contributing to neural dysfunction.

questions.text: The best diagnostic modality for tuberculosis of the spine is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CT-guided transpedicular vertebral biopsy is the gold standard for confirming spinal tuberculosis.

  • It provides a definitive diagnosis through histopathological and microbiological confirmation.
  • MRI is highly sensitive and is used for early diagnosis and to assess soft tissue, spinal cord, and the extent of paravertebral abscess, but it is not confirmatory.
  • Sputum and blood cultures may occasionally help, especially in disseminated TB, but their diagnostic yield in spinal TB is low.
  • Early diagnosis through imaging should always be followed by biopsy in atypical or non-responsive cases.

Explanation of other options:

Blood culture (Option A): Rarely positive in skeletal TB; not a definitive test.

Sputum culture (Option B): Useful in pulmonary TB but not reliable in isolated spinal TB.

MRI (Option C): Excellent for detecting extent and soft tissue involvement.

Key Takeaway:

MRI is the investigation of choice for extent; CT-guided biopsy is the gold standard for definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: The Commonest site for tuberculous spondylitis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The majority of cases are reported in the dorsolumbar region(lower thoracic and upper lumbar) due to:

  • Greater extent of movement - stress zone due to transition of kyphosis to lordosis
  • Degree of weight bearing
  • Large surface area of spongy cancellous bone
  • Proximity to the cisterna chyli and the kidney.

In order of involvement lumbar → upper dorsal → cervical → sacral → atlantoaxial

Explanation of other options:

T3-T5 (Option B): Less frequently involved; upper dorsal spine is less affected compared to the dorsolumbar.

T1-T4 (Option C): Rarely involved in TB spine; not a stress junction zone.

L4-;L5 (Option D): The Lower lumbar region is less commonly involved than T12-L1.

Key Takeaway:

T12-L1 is the most commonly affected site in tuberculous spondylitis due to anatomical stress and vascular predisposition.

choices.text: Continue anti-tubercular therapy and monitor for another month
Add corticosteroids and reassess in 2 weeks
Refer for surgical decompression and stabilisation
Stop ATT and switch to second-line anti-TB drugs

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, and progressive back pain. MRI of the thoracic spine shows vertebral body destruction at T9-T10 with a paravertebral abscess and mild spinal cord compression. He was started on anti-tubercular therapy (ATT). After 6 weeks, he develops progressive lower limb weakness and difficulty walking. Neurological examination reveals spastic paraparesis with increased deep tendon reflexes and bilateral Babinski sign. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Progressive neurological deterioration despite ATT is an absolute indication for surgical decompression in spinal TB.

  • Surgical intervention is warranted when there is a progressive neurological deficit despite adequate medical therapy.
  • Goals of surgery include decompression, drainage of abscess, and stabilisation to prevent further cord injury.
  • Absolute indications:
    • Paraparesis which do not show the signs of progressive recovery on conservative therapy.
    • Paraparesis that develops during conservative treatment
    • Paraparesis, which becomes worse on conservative therapy
    • Patients with a recurrence of paraparesis.
    • Patients of cervical spine tuberculosis have a large prevertebral abscess, causing dyspnea or difficulty in deglutition.
    • Grade 4 paraplegia.
  • Relative indications:
    • Paraplegia with onset in old age
    • Painful paraplegia.
  • Rare indications:
    • Spinal tumour syndrome
    • Cauda equina syndrome
    • Posterior spinal disease.

Explanation of other options:

Continue ATT and monitor for another month (Option A): Delay surgical intervention despite worsening neurology.

Add corticosteroids and reassess in 2 weeks (Option B): Steroids may reduce inflammation, but are not definitive for cord compression.

Stop ATT and switch to second-line anti-TB drugs (Option D): No evidence of drug resistance; inappropriate step without microbiological confirmation.

Key Takeaway:

Progressive neurological deficit on ATT is an absolute indication for decompressive surgery in spinal TB.

questions.text: The earliest neurological sign in a patient with TB spine is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ankle clonus is the first clinical indicator of corticospinal tract involvement in spinal tuberculosis.

  • In spinal TB, anterior compression affects the motor tracts (corticospinal) first due to their anterior anatomical location.
  • Flowchart depicting the sequential neurological signs in spinal tuberculosis:
  • Recognising early signs like clonus is critical for timely intervention to prevent irreversible deficits.

Explanation of other options:

Sensory loss (Option A): Sensory tracts are located posteriorly and are affected later.

Spastic weakness (Option B): Motor weakness appears after initial UMN signs like clonus and extensor plantar.

Extensor plantar response (Option C): Appears after clonus; it is an early but not the earliest sign.

Key Takeaway:

Ankle clonus is the first neurological sign in spinal TB, preceding plantar response and motor weakness.

questions.text: Apparent lengthening of the limb is seen in which stage of TB hip?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Apparent lengthening occurs in Stage 1 due to joint effusion positioning the limb in flexion, abduction, and external rotation.

Stages Of TB Hip:

The disease process progresses through the following clinical stages:

  • Stage 1 (Stage of tubercular synovitis): Due to synovitis, there is joint effusion and the joint is held in a position of maximum capacity, i.e., flexion, abduction and external rotation, causing apparent lengthening. On X-ray, all that is visible is a widened joint space due to effusion and generalised osteopenia.
  • Stage 2 (Stage of early arthritis): With the advancement of the disease process, there is destruction of articular cartilage. With spasm of flexors and adductors of the hip, there is flexion, adduction and internal rotation deformity with apparent shortening. True shortening is also present due to damage to articular cartilage, but is less than 1 cm. X-ray shows a decrease in joint space and osteopenia.
  • Stage 3 (Stage of late arthritis): With further destruction, clinical signs of flexion, adduction, internal rotation deformities and apparent shortening are exaggerated. True shortening is more than 1 cm. Here is a gross restriction of movements and muscle wasting. X-rays may show complete loss of joint space with destruction of the head/acetabulum.
  • Stage 4 (Late arthritis with subluxation/dislocation): There are flexion, adduction and internal rotation deformities with gross shortening. With destruction of the acetabulum, femur head and ligaments, the upper end of the femur may displace upwards and dorsally, leaving the lower part of the acetabulum empty but forming a false acetabulum higher up (wandering acetabulum).

Explanation of other options:

Stage 2 (Option B): Early arthritis stage; joint starts showing cartilage destruction with apparent and true shortening due to adduction and internal rotation.

Stage 3 (Option C): Late arthritis; deformities worsen, and true shortening is more than 1 cm due to bony destruction.

Stage 4 (Option D): Subluxation/dislocation phase; gross true shortening occurs due to proximal and posterior displacement of the femoral head (wandering acetabulum).

Key Takeaway:

Apparent limb lengthening is a hallmark of early TB synovitis of the hip (Stage 1) due to muscle relaxation and joint positioning.

questions.text: The most common organism causing osteomyelitis in post-operative patients is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Staphylococcus aureus is the leading cause of osteomyelitis in postoperative and implant-associated infections.

  • It accounts for more than 50% of osteomyelitis cases, particularly in postoperative and implant-associated settings.
  • Staph aureus is highly virulent, capable of biofilm formation, and adheres well to prosthetic surfaces and necrotic bone.
  • It spreads via direct inoculation (surgery/trauma), contiguous spread, or hematogenous routes.
  • Almost all orthopaedic infections, be it osteomyelitis or septic arthritis, are caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Explanation of other options:

Group B Streptococcus (Option B): More commonly implicated in neonatal infections, not the leading cause in postoperative adults.

Enterococcus (Option C): May be involved in polymicrobial infections, but rarely the primary pathogen.

Salmonella (Option D): Classically associated with osteomyelitis in sickle cell disease, not postoperative cases.

Key Takeaway:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common pathogen in postoperative osteomyelitis due to its virulence and biofilm-forming ability.

questions.text: In acute osteomyelitis, how much time is required for the formation of an abscess after entry of a bacterium into the bone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Abscess formation typically begins around 24 hours after bacterial invasion of bone in acute osteomyelitis.

  • Once bacteria enter the metaphysis via hematogenous spread, the infection quickly progresses.
  • Inflammation, oedema, and exudation develop in the marrow cavity within hours.
  • Abscess formation occurs within 24 hours, leading to increased intramedullary pressure and vascular compromise.
  • If untreated, this leads to necrosis, sequestrum formation, and sinus tract development.
  • The flow chart of the steps of osteomyelitis is given below:

Explanation of other options:

12 hours (Option A): Too early; at this stage, inflammatory changes begin, but not enough time for abscess formation.

48 hours (Option C): By this point, there is already well-formed pus and vascular thrombosis; abscess forms earlier.

72 hours (Option D): Represents progression to sequestrum and systemic symptoms, beyond the initial abscess stage.

Key Takeaway:

Abscess formation in acute osteomyelitis typically occurs within 24 hours of bacterial entry due to a rapid inflammatory response.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 1-week history of worsening pain and swelling in his right femur. He has a fever of 39°C, and laboratory studies reveal elevated white blood cell count and CRP. Imaging reveals a lytic lesion in the femoral diaphysis with periosteal elevation and a radiolucent channel communicating from the medullary cavity to the external surface of the bone. What is the most likely explanation for the radiologic finding described?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cloaca refers to the radiological channel in the involucrum through which pus drains from the medullary cavity to the exterior.

  • In chronic osteomyelitis, pus within the bone creates pressure that leads to the formation of a channel.
  • This channel is known as the cloaca, allowing drainage through the involucrum.
  • The involucrum is the sheath of new bone formed around dead bone.
  • The sinus is an external opening in the skin, which may connect with the cloaca via a tract.
  • Cloaca is a diagnostic clue in imaging for chronic osteomyelitis, particularly when combined with sequestrum and involucrum.

Explanation of other options:

Sinus (Option A): External skin opening; the radiolucent tract seen in bone is not a sinus.

Sequestrum (Option C): Dead bone fragment in the cavity, seen as a dense area; not a channel.

Involucrum (Option D): Layer of new bone around infected bone; the channel is cloaca, not the involucrum itself.

Key Takeaway:

Cloaca is the opening in the involucrum through which pus escapes in chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a discharging sinus over the upper arm for the last 3 months. X-ray of the humerus reveals extensive new bone formation encasing a central dense necrotic segment. Identify the labelled structure indicated in the radiograph.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows severe chronic osteomyelitis of the humerus in a child. Unfortunately, the entire humerus of the child is dead and has become a sequestrum. However, there is new bone formation circumferentially around the sequestrum. This is the involucrum, which is the marked structure.

Explanation of other options:

Sequestrum (Option A): Dense, necrotic fragment of bone, often seen centrally; not the encasing structure.

Cloaca (Option C): A sinus opening in the involucrum; radiologically appears as a tract, not the bony sheath.

Callus (Option D): Reparative bone after fracture, unrelated to the pathology of osteomyelitis.

Key Takeaway:

Involucrum is the reactive new bone formed around a sequestrum in chronic osteomyelitis, often visible as a sheath on imaging.

questions.text: Ring sequestrum is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ring sequestrum is typically formed around external fixation pins due to chronic pin-tract infection.

  • A ring sequestrum refers to a circular fragment of necrosed bone, often seen surrounding pin tracts in cases of chronic pin-tract infection.
  • It develops due to ischemic necrosis of the bone encircling the pin, leading to circumferential dead bone.
  • Occasionally seen in amputation stumps with chronic infection, but most classically described with external fixators.
  • It can lead to loosening of the pin and chronic discharging sinuses.

Explanation of other options:

Fungal osteomyelitis (Option A): Typically causes diffuse bone destruction; not associated with ring sequestrum.

Gunshot injuries (Option B): May produce irregular comminuted sequestra, not ring-shaped.

Post skull trephination (Option C): May show flat bone sequestra, but not classical ring formation.

Key Takeaway:

Ring sequestrum is a circumferential necrosed bone fragment seen around external fixation pins in chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: 35 year 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with a discharging sinus in his right leg. He gives a history of an open fracture of the right tibia 8 months back, which was treated at a local hospital. He complains that sometimes, there is expulsion of tiny bone pieces through the sinus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A discharging sinus with expulsion of bone fragments is pathognomonic of chronic osteomyelitis.

  • Chronic osteomyelitis typically presents with a discharging sinus, often months after the initial infection or trauma.
  • A key diagnostic feature is the elimination of sequestrum (dead bone) via the sinus tract.
  • The history of open fracture and delayed onset further supports chronicity.
  • Imaging often shows involucrum and cloaca formation.
  • Management usually involves debridement and long-term antibiotics.

Explanation of other options:

Acute osteomyelitis (Option A): Presents with rapid onset of pain, fever, swelling, not usually with sinus formation or expelled bone pieces.

Subacute osteomyelitis (Option B): Occurs with milder symptoms; sinus with bone fragments is uncommon.

Nonunion tibia (Option D): Presents with pain and abnormal mobility at the fracture site, not sinus or bone fragment expulsion.

Key Takeaway:

A discharging sinus with bone fragments after prior fracture strongly indicates chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding chronic osteomyelitis is not true?
1. Sinus is a clinical hallmark of chronic osteomyelitis
2. Sequestrum is the pathological hallmark of chronic osteomyelitis, which is a live bone
3. Saucerisation is stopped before the paprika sign is visible
4. Causes pseudoparalysis in children
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sequestrum is dead bone, not live; saucerization is done until paprika sign (healthy bleeding bone) appears; pseudoparalysis occurs in acute, not chronic, osteomyelitis.

  • Sequestrum is the pathological hallmark of chronic osteomyelitis and refers to a dead piece of bone that has separated from viable bone.
  • Sinus tract formation is the clinical hallmark; it serves as a drainage route for chronic infection.
  • Saucerization is a surgical procedure to expose infected bone, and it is stopped when healthy punctate bleeding is seen (paprika sign).
  • Pseudoparalysis is typical of acute osteomyelitis or scurvy, where the child avoids movement due to pain, not seen in chronic osteomyelitis.

Explanation of other options:

Option 2: Sequestrum is dead bone, not living.

Option 3: Saucerisation is continued until paprika sign appears.

Option 4: Pseudoparalysis occurs in acute osteomyelitis, not chronic.

Key Takeaway:

Dead bone (sequestrum), draining sinus, and the need for saucerization till paprika sign are hallmarks of chronic osteomyelitis.
